theoretical_framework.main_concept: The study is based on the premise that surges in sympathetic activity during the hypnopompic period (ending of sleep) impact heart rate variability (HRV), potentially predicting cardiovascular disease (CVD) events.

underlying_principles.description: Increased sympathetic activity is believed to be a contributing factor to cardiovascular incidents, particularly at the end of nocturnal sleep.

HRV is widely used to assess autonomic nervous system function related to heart control and is divided into time domain and frequency domain analysis. Complexity-based, entropy measures provide additional insights.
Recent studies indicate that entropy measures, which consider the complexity and non-linear dynamics of HRV, can better predict adverse cardiovascular outcomes than traditional HRV measures.
Machine learning models such as Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) were employed to integrate HRV data and conventional CVD risk factors, showing superior predictive capabilities for CVD outcomes.

relation_to_existing_theories.autonomic_control: HRV is a known marker for autonomic nervous system balance, with altered HRV observed in various cardiovascular conditions.
relation_to_existing_theories.neurocardiology: This research aligns with neurocardiology principles, linking autonomic and central nervous system interactions to heart function and disease prediction.

theoretical_framework.aims_of_study: The study aims to evaluate the potential of hypnopompic HRV as a short-term predictor of CVD incidents and test the efficacy of entropy-based HRV measures in enhancing prediction accuracy.

methodologies.description: Multiscale Sample Entropy (MSE) and Modified Permutation Entropy (MPE) were utilized to assess the complexity of HRV.
Used to construct predictive models, incorporating both typical CVD risk factors and HRV metrics.
